sub_title: Owner and Founder Terra Cotta Incognita | Senior KNA Specialist Materials | (Post-)Medieval Pottery Specialist | Public-oriented Archeological Publications | PhD Candidate
summary:
Terra Cotta Incognita is een Archeologische Onderzoek & Ontwerp Studio, gevestigd in Zaandijk/Amsterdam en opgericht door Nina Linde Jaspers in 2009. Zij werkt nationaal en internationaal aan archeologische en kunsthistorische projecten samen met een breed scala aan specialisten, wetenschappers, archeologen en kunstenaars. Oog voor detail en een bredere interdisciplinaire visie gaan hand in hand. Haar freelance projecten & academisch onderzoek naar laatmiddeleeuws en vroegmodern gebruiksaardewerk (d.w.z. productie, uitwisseling, gebruik en typologie) bundelt zij onder de vlag van Terra Cotta Incognita. Daarnaast werkt ze omvangrijk oud, ongepubliceerd archeologisch onderzoek uit volgens de huidige archeologische maatstaven.

Onderzoek
Speciale belangstelling gaat uit naar vroegmoderne keramiek die via internationale maritieme handel is uitgewisseld, archeometrische herkomst- en distributiestudies naar internationaal uitgewisseld tinglazuuraardewerk en analyses van productieafval en productlijnen van keramische werkplaatsen.

Ontwerp
Een voorliefde voor de combinatie van grafisch ontwerp, artistieke fotografie, illustraties en inhoudelijk archeologisch onderzoek naar materiële cultuur versterkt het archeologische verhaal op een visueel expressieve manier. Resultaten van verschillende archeologische materiële deelonderzoeken (bijv. keramiek, glas, hout, metaal, textiel, archeozoölogisch, archeobotanisch, etc.) worden gesynthetiseerd en geïntegreerd in één verhaal en gepresenteerd in prachtige stilleven fotografie.

treasury_media.title: What and whom do we serve?
treasury_media.description: Terra Cotta Incognita works interdisciplinary by cooperating with professionals and volunteers from a wide range of backgrounds in science and arts. For the study of late medieval and early modern maritime trade ceramics we maintain a national and international network of specialists. We publish popular books on archaeology and well-designed scientific reports. Furthermore we process old archaeological research by modern digital standards and explore various teaching activities and lectures.

treasury_media.title: Terra Cotta Incognita: for a wider horizon
treasury_media.description: For a wider audience we coordinate, co-write, design, edit, produce and publish popular books on regional archaeology. The books are well designed and richly illustrated with high quality still life photography and illustrations of historical reconstructions based on archaeological research. These popular books search for a wider horizon by summarizing archaeological research that has been published in numerous archaeological reports and present the most important outcomes to a larger public.

treasury_media.title: Terra Cotta Incognita Specials
treasury_media.description: The Terra Cotta Incognita Specials is a series of archaeological reports written by material culture specialists, well designed and richly illustrated with high quality photography and catalogues, while maintaining the scientific standard for specialists in the field. This makes it attractive for a wider audience and for archaeological specialists alike. The specials’ subjects are cherry-picked: they really need to be something special, with high relevance to specialists in the working field.

awards.title: H.J.E. van Beuningen Prize
awards.description:
On the 14th of April 2011 Hendrik Jan van Beuningen has handed out the H.J.E. van Beuningen Prize to Nina Jaspers on behalf of the Dutch Utensils Foundation. The Foundation, the objective of which is “the increase of knowledge of the pre-industrial utensil”, particularly within the Dutch cultural area, instituted the prize in 1991 in order to encourage research in this field. 

Laudatio:

Her award is primarily for her MA-thesis "Clean and truly enjoyable. Italian import ceramics in Dutch soil." The two articles in "Vormen uit Vuur" were a decisive factor in this, as they summarize the main results of the research and open them up to a wider audience. In addition, the article "Met de Franse slag. French compendiariofaience from Dutch soil (c. 1600-1660)" further deepens the thesis topic. Besides Italy, French tin-glazed earthenware is now discussed. [...] The research has not only been received with great enthusiasm among Dutch archaeologists, the results have not gone unnoticed in Italy either. In the realization of the Vlissingen Dokkershaven publication also presented today, Jaspers also played an important role. Among other things, she proves in this publication the importance of the results from her thesis and further demonstrates that broader archaeological research on material culture is also in good hands with her. In short, entirely in line with the objective of the prize that aims to stimulate research on the material culture of the pre-industrial Netherlands.

profile_positions.title: KNA Senior Specialist Materialen (Actor Registratie Nummer 59458184)

profile_positions.description:
Elaboration of old archaeological research of the St Servatius complex in Maastricht: archaeologically unlocking the Merovingian and Karolingian burial field with grave finds and the architectural history of the Roman, Merovingian, Carolingian and Ottoman periods in cooperation with dr. M. Kars & Prof.dr. F.C.W.J. Theuws.

Excavations: 

- St Servatius Pandhof (8 trenches): ROB excavation 1953-1954.
- St Servatius Stiftskapel (2 trenches) & Basilica (40 trenches): municipal excavations 1981-1989.
profile_positions.title: Archaeological Researcher Servatius Project

profile_positions.description:
- Vertalingswerkzaamheden t.b.v. de "English Terminology" op de website van het Deventer Systeem
- Ontwikkeling kleurenschema's voor bakselgroepen volgens Deventer Systeem
- Automatiseringen doorvoeren voor het toekennen van de kleurcodes aan grafieken in Excel
- Digitalisering van de analoge opzoekschema's van het Deventer Systeem
- Schrijven van de gebruikershandleiding en het stappenplan voor publicatie in Deventer Systeem
- Opstellen van lokale typochronologiën
- Lid van de Redactie Deventer Systeem (2011-2014)
profile_positions.title: Deventer Systeem: ondersteunende werkzaamheden, vertaling & ontwikkeling
Het Verdronken Dorp Etersheim: aardewerkanalyse en -rapportage

profile_positions.description: Bi-annual guest lecturer combined with a full day excursion for MA-students of the Master Course "Conservation and Restoration of Cultural Heritage" at the University of Amsterdam. We visit, study ánd touch the production waste of Manufacturers of 17th and 18th century Delftware in the city of Delft.
profile_positions.title: Guest Lecturer & Delft Excursion Master Course "Conservation and Restoration of Cultural Heritage"

profile_positions.description: Onderzoek naar het productieafval van een laatmiddeleeuwse pottenbakker op de Branderskamp in Ermelo. Met de hele productlijn in een Deventer Systeem catalogus, stereoscopische analyses van de mineralogische samenstelling van baksel en magering (m.m.v. het Material Culture Lab van de Universiteit Leiden) en historische illustraties.
profile_positions.title: Terra Cotta Incognita Special nr. 3: Misbaksels uit Ermelo
Palmhoutwrak/ Wrak van De Jurk (BZN17): aardewerkanalyse en -rapportage

profile_positions.description: The identification of the ceramic finds excavated on the 16th-19th century shipyards located on the Hogendijk in Zaandam. Many international maritime trade ceramics (Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, French...) as well as thousands of objects that were manufactured in various parts the Netherlands. The pottery analysis was done by the guidelines of the Deventer System (Hogendijk I&II: a total of almost 36,000 fragments).
profile_positions.title: Shipyard Hogendijk I & II in Zaandam: Pottery Identification

profile_positions.description:
Pottery identification and analyses of 17th & 18th century Dutch whalers settlements in the West-Fjords of Iceland and the identification and analyses of the tin glazed ceramic cargo of Shipwreck "De Melckmeyt" (1659). 

Icelandic Research Fund Project by Ragnar Edvardsson: “Allen die willen naar Island gaan” Dutch whaling and trading in Iceland in the 17th and 18th centuries"
profile_positions.title: Dutch Whaling and Trading in the Westfjords of Iceland: Early Modern Pottery Specialist

profile_positions.description: Late medieval and early modern ceramics from archaeological sites in the Netherlands
profile_positions.title: Guest Lecturer

skills: Deventer System Typology for Late and Post Medieval Ceramics and Glass
